statement.tex: %text Write the direction-cosines of the line joining the points $(1,0,0)$ and $(0,1,1)$. %

options.tex: %text The direction ratios of the line joining $(1,0,0)$ and $(0,1,1)$ are $a=-1$, $b=1$ and $c=1$. %

reason.tex: %text Direction ratios of a line joining points $(x_1, y_1, z_1)$ and $(x_2, y_2, z_2)$ are given by $(x_2-x_2)$, $(y_2-y_1)$ and $(z_2-z_1)$. Therefore, for the given line the direction ratios would be $-1$, $1$ and $1$ (or even $1$, $-1$ and $-1$). It doesn't matter which point's coordinate is subtracted from which! %

options.tex: %text Given the set of direction ratios $-1$, $1$ and $1$, the direction cosines would be $-\sqrt{3}, \sqrt{3}, \sqrt{3}$. %
